posts.name: Krypton #9487
posts.cooked:
Hello everyone, we are trying to update our odometry using limelight with mt2, we can read some apriltags and get the correct position, while others, we read and the robot is in the incorrect position, but reading the apriltag

Does anyone know what it could be? image 1245×685 56.3 KB

image 1245×685 56.3 KB

image 1245×685 56.3 KB
Are you sure that you are using the correct fmap? Are you also updating the gyro yaw as that is required for MT2?

posts.name: Krypton #9487
posts.cooked:
First, what would fmap be? and second, we use yaw, and when I set yaw to 0, some apriltags are correct, but as soon as I set yaw to 180, the same thing happens, but with inverted apriltags.

Would seeing my code help you?

fmap is how to the limelight know where all of the tags are located and can be downloaded from Downloads | Limelight Documentation . But more likely, you issue is that for MT2 to work correctly, you need to constantly supply the yaw from the robot gyro when you get the pose estimate: Robot Localization with MegaTag2 | Limelight Documentation ex: Robot Localization with MegaTag2 | Limelight Documentation .

posts.name: william belk
posts.cooked:
I’m convinced MegaTag2 is reading the back of April tags. Hopefully we can find a solution IMG_7355 3024×4032 4.51 MB IMG_7352 3024×4032 3.71 MB IMG_7351 3024×4032 4.22 MB

IMG_7352 3024×4032 3.71 MB

IMG_7351 3024×4032 4.22 MB

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Megatag2 relies on knowing which direction your robot is facing. Make sure you’re updating your robot’s yaw value so it can give you accurate measurements, as someone else said earlier in the thread.

posts.name: william belk
posts.cooked: Unfortunately I am doing that already. I even created a trigger to reset my odometry, the LL orientation, and pigeon. Now when I press the corresponding button the MT2 will jump for a millisecond and then return. To its previous crazy spot.

posts.name: william belk
posts.cooked: I wish I could find a way to push an update with a pose in it to the MT2 Kalman filter.
Can you upload here the code where you update your limelight with the robot orientation, also did you configure your limelight’s position in robot space?
Is your limelight rotated on the robot at all? If so you need to indicate that in the pipeline and assuming you’re updating the gyro angle correctly then this may be an issue.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Yes MegaTag2 does appear to read the back of a tag if you have your gyro that you send to LL backwards.

posts.name: william belk
posts.cooked:
I will tryout this fix today!!! Thanks!

The LL is rotated (on the back of the robot). And I am just sending the robot body’s yawl. I must have assumed the update orientation was intended to update the robot’s orientation, since the transform is already in the LL (camera in robot space).

posts.name: william belk
posts.cooked: Yep. I probably just needed to read the API better to see the typical transformation is not applied for this function and ‘ SetRobotOrientation’ is really ‘ SetLLOrientation’

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
william.belk:

‘ SetRobotOrientation’

This is the gyro reading at every iterative loop execution. The camera orientation WRT the robot is set once in your LL dashboard.

posts.name: Benjamin Miller
posts.cooked:
We had this issue, the problem is that when you use setRobotOrientation the gyro needs to face the red alience wall. Our fix (courtesy of NoMythics code, shoutout) was to flip gyro 180 when on red alliance, and also invert driving controls when on red allience IMG_1767 2556×1179 285 KB IMG_1768 2556×1179 275 KB IMG_1769 2556×1179 292 KB

IMG_1767 2556×1179 285 KB

IMG_1767 2556×1179 285 KB

IMG_1768 2556×1179 275 KB

IMG_1768 2556×1179 275 KB

IMG_1769 2556×1179 292 KB

IMG_1769 2556×1179 292 KB

In that case, you most likely need “180” in the “ LL Yaw” field of the advanced tab. I honestly think instead of adding all of that it’s simpler to provide the raw gyro angle (possible IEEEremaindered between -180 and 180) and setting the yaw to 180 in the pipeline. Hopefully that helps!

You also need to provide the BLUE rotation, which means 0 degrees is facing the red alliance wall even if you are on your red alliance. Supposing your gyro being 0 always means facing the opponent alliance (which it should be in a match), you could detect when you’re on read and add 180 degrees to the gyro angle, which you then supply to the SetRobotOoientation.
